awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Extinction and Diversification Dynamics of Archosauria Through Early Mesozoic Climate Crises
awd_abstract_narration:
Two mass extinctions occurred early in the Mesozoic Era shortly after dinosaurs appeared, and multiple lines of evidence suggest that dramatic global climate change events were contributing factors. This project will investigate the response of the extinct relatives of birds and crocodilians (the Archosauria) to these episodes. The primary objectives of this study are to analyze the evolutionary relationships of fossil archosaurs, and use these evolutionary relationships as a framework to investigate how archosaur respiratory anatomy and body temperature regulation changed after the extinctions at the end of the Triassic Period and during the Early Jurassic Epoch. The study will test the hypothesis that global warming events initiated evolutionary changes in respiratory anatomy and contributed to currently unexplained patterns of extinction and diversification of extinct archosaurs, including dinosaurs. This research will provide insight into the ways that vertebrate communities on land respond to rapid changes in climate, and may help to predict which species will experience an increased risk of extinction during modern climate change. This research will provide multiple opportunities for undergraduate training. In addition, educational materials based on the results will be distributed to educators at secondary and higher education levels, as well as disseminated in the form of scientific papers and presentations at professional meetings.

Time-calibrated phylogenies of Archosauria will be estimated using both parsimony analyses of morphology and combined-evidence Bayesian approaches to phylogeny reconstruction incorporating molecular sequence data from extant archosaurs. Character transformation rates for respiratory-related characters (e.g. postcranial skeletal pneumaticity) and non-respiratory characters will be modeled iteratively over a large sample of time-calibrated trees to account for uncertainty in phylogeny and chronology. Non-parametric statistics will be used to test for the presence of rate-shifts in respiratory character evolution surrounding the interval of extinctions and associated climate changes in the early Mesozoic Era.

por.por_cntn:
Josef Stiegler has completed work on his dissertation titled: "Anatomy, Systematics, and Paleobiology of Noasaurid Ceratosaurs from the Late Jurassic of China." A major aspect of his dissertation was formulating a new hypothesis for the evolutionary relationships of theropod dinosaurs. This NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant (entitled: "DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Extinction and Diversification Dynamics of Archosauria Through Early Mesozoic Climate Crises") allowed him to expand the scope of his work on the evolutionary relationships of dinosaurs to study a broader group of organisms to which dinosaurs belong, the Archosauria.

During the Mesozoic Era the Archosauria dominated terrestrial ecosystems and included birds, non-avian dinosaurs, pterosaurs, and the relatives of modern crocodylians. Many of these organisms were characterized by skeletal pneumaticity—outpocketings of the respiratory tract that can invade bones of the skull, vertebrae, ribs, or limb skeleton and create air spaces within them. Some studies have speculated on the original functional significance of archosaur skeletal pneumaticity, often proposing relationships between pneumaticity and respiratory efficiency or body size. However, the adaptive value of pneumaticity to the organisms that first evolved these elaborate systems remains a mystery. Interestingly, several lineages of archosaurs that independently evolved distinct pneumatic systems in one or both of the base of the skull and the postcranial skeleton survived two mass extinction events associated with catastrophic changes in climate, and many archosaur lineages that lacked extensive pneumatic systems went extinct. The primary goals of this study were to generate a large evolutionary tree of archosaurs, create new quantitative methods for measuring rates of morphological change related to skeletal pneumaticity, and to test hypotheses regarding the potential relationship between skeletal pneumaticity and survival through major Mesozoic climatic events.

During the grant period, Josef Stiegler accomplished these goals and presented various aspects of this work at annual meetings of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology. Mapping the pneumatic features observed on the evolutionary tree of archosaurs shows that newly evolved pneumatic morphologies often first appeared following abrupt climatic changes associated with major vertebrate extinction events. Time series data for evolutionary rates of change in pneumatic systems showed interesting correlations with atmospheric oxygenation (the rate of change of oxygen in the atmosphere) and atmospheric temperature; however, significant uncerntainty in the timing of lineage diversification and acquisition of pneumatic features posed difficulties in confidently interpreting hypothesis tests. The original adaptive value of skeletal pneumaticity to archosaurs and the reasons for the differential survival of archosaurs with elaborate pneumatic systems remain elusive.

Josef Stiegler's work on this project involved the collection of computed tomographic (CT) data, and provided opportunities for undergraduate students and a Masters student to receive training in the processing of that data. Additionally, the project allowed Stiegler to meet and work with international researchers, fostering new colaborative projects.


Last Modified: 08/29/2021
Modified by: James M Clark
